title: Simple Greetings & Goodbyes
objectives: Build confidence in greeting people in English using basic words
Learn polite ways to say Hello and Goodbye
Mix short Hindi for comfort without losing politeness
Enjoy small talk without feeling awkward

activities.text: Namaste & Welcome to Lesson 2! Aaj hum seekhenge 'Greetings & Goodbyes'—yaani aapka pehla ‘Hello’ aur aakhri ‘Bye’ kaise magical ho sakta hai!

activities.caption: Imagine: Aap ek dost ya new coworker se mil rahe ho . Pehla impression hi sab kuch hai!

activities.text: Is lesson mein hum basic greetings seekhenge—like 'Hello', 'Hi', 'Goodbye', etc. Par dhyan rahe ki tone & smile sabse important hai!

vocabItems.meaning: A simple universal greeting, ‘Namaste’ vibe in English.
Friendly parting phrase, suggests you’ll meet again quickly.
Express happiness in meeting someone new.

activities.sentence: ______! My name is Priya. How are you?
hints: Short greeting, English me sabse common word!

feedback.correctText: Yes, ‘Hello’ is perfect to start a conversation politely!
feedback.wrongText: Try ‘Hello’—short, universal, easy. ‘Hi’ also works but let’s pick the standard answer.

activities.question: Aap greeting karne se pahle sabse zyada kya sochte ho?
options: Meri English theek hai ya nahi?

dynamicFeedback.0: Grammar chhodo—short & sweet English enough hai Greeting ke liye!
dynamicFeedback.2: 2-3 lines enough for a greeting—koi essay nahi!
dynamicFeedback.3: Wah, that’s great! Keep it up!

activities.sentence: It was ______ (nice/boring) to meet you. See you soon!
hints: After a greeting, you show positivity with ‘nice’

feedback.correctText: Yes! Always be positive. ‘Nice to meet you’ sets a good tone.
feedback.wrongText: ‘Boring’ would be rude or negative, na? Politeness chahiye!

activities.question: Which greeting is best for a new coworker in an office?
hints: Formal or semi-formal environment—polite English phrase is ideal.

activities.caption: Office scenario: Meeting your new teammate politely.

activities.text: Dekho, formal ya new person ke liye ‘Hello, nice to meet you’ is best. Bhai/Yaarr is good for close friends only!

activities.sentence: Hi, I’m Rahul. ______ (Nice to meet/Go away) you!

feedback.correctText: Spot on! ‘Nice to meet you’ is a friendly starter.

activities.prompt: Bolkar practice: ‘Hello, my name is ____. Nice to meet you!’ Louder, with a smile!

hints: Short casual greeting before you chat further

feedback.correctText: Yes! Start with ‘Hi, how’s your day?’— super casual & friendly!

activities.instruction: Identify the inappropriate word for this situation.
activities.originalSentence: Yo man! Can you help me with directions, please?
activities.explanation: ‘Yo’ is too informal for speaking to an older or formally dressed person. A polite greeting like 'Excuse me' would be better.

activities.question: Which ‘goodbye’ is gentle & polite, not rude?

activities.caption: At a friend’s house: Time to leave politely with a smile!

activities.sentence: Okay, I should go now. ______ (Goodbye/Hello), take care!
hints: Hindi: ‘Chalta hoon!’ but English me polite alternative

feedback.correctText: Yes! ‘Goodbye, take care!’ is perfect to end politely!
feedback.wrongText: Wrong. ‘Hello’ is for starting, not ending!

activities.sentence: It was really ______ (nice/bad) talking with you. Let’s do this again!
hints: You want to compliment the meeting, so ‘nice’ is typical

feedback.correctText: Yes! Spreading positivity is key to goodbyes.
feedback.wrongText: No negativity—avoid harsh or random words!

activities.question: Aapke liye goodbye bolna sabse mushkil kab hota hai?
options: Close friend se milkar jab alag hona hota hai
Formal events, not sure what to say

dynamicFeedback.0: Office me a short polite line works: ‘Alright, talk soon!’
dynamicFeedback.1: Emotional? ‘Bye, see you soon, keep in touch!’ helps
dynamicFeedback.2: Formal event? ‘Thank you for your time, goodbye!’ is safe.
dynamicFeedback.3: That’s nice—some people are just naturals!

scenes.text: Scenario 1: Bumped into an old friend at a mall—greeting them: “Hey, long time! Nice to see you.”
Scenario 2: Meeting a group briefly: “Hello everyone, hope you’re doing good!”
When leaving: 'It was awesome catching up! See you soon!'
Lesson moral: Use warm lines, a smile, & genuine tone. Koi fancy grammar zaroori nahi!

activities.instruction: Build a super short greeting. 2 letters only!

activities.caption: A short but powerful greeting can open hearts!

activities.text: ‘Hi’ is casual, but effective. If you want formal, use ‘Hello.’ Dono me smile is must!

hints: Asking about well-being? Start with ‘Hi’ or ‘Hello’ not ‘Bye’

feedback.correctText: Right! ‘Hi’ is perfect for a friendly check-in.
feedback.wrongText: Wrong—If you say ‘Bye’, conversation ends immediately!

activities.instruction: Spot the word that feels rude:
activities.originalSentence: Hey! Move aside, I want to say hello to my Friend.
activities.explanation: ‘Move aside’ sounds rude. In a friendly greeting, we should not push someone away!

activities.question: When you say ‘Bye’ to family/friends, do you use English words or Hindi?

dynamicFeedback.0: Try short English lines to practice daily!
dynamicFeedback.1: Wah, keep it up! This lesson will refine your usage.
dynamicFeedback.2: Hinglish is great—just keep tone positive!
dynamicFeedback.3: Observing your own habit helps improvement!

activities.sentence: It was ______ (fun/sad) meeting you. Let’s catch up soon!
hints: Positivity after meeting someone is good courtesy.

feedback.correctText: Yes, ‘fun meeting you’ is a nice vibe.

activities.question: Which is a polite goodbye to a coworker?

activities.prompt: Verbal practice: ‘Hey, great to see you!’ loudly Bolo with smile

feedback.correctText: Yes, ‘Goodbye, let’s keep in touch!’ is perfect parting line.
feedback.wrongText: ‘Hello’ is a greeting, not a goodbye.

activities.caption: Imagine you’re leaving a friend’s party,use polite farewell lines!

activities.sentence: It was ______ (nice/bad) talking with you. Let’s do this again!

activities.question: Best quick greeting for new buddy?

activities.prompt: Say out loud: ‘Hi, good to see you. How’ve you been?’

activities.question: What is your biggest challenge in saying goodbyes?

dynamicFeedback.0: Keep a short line ready: ‘Nice meeting you, see you soon!’
dynamicFeedback.1: It’s normal! Try gentle lines: ‘Take care!’
dynamicFeedback.2: Add a small reason or positive phrase, so not abrupt!

activities.sentence: Alright, I gotta go. ______ (Bye/Hello) for now!

feedback.correctText: Yes! ‘Bye for now’ is a friendly short parting line.
feedback.wrongText: Wrong—Hello is for starting, not ending!

activities.originalSentence: Hey you, bye never mind, I'm ignoring you.
activities.explanation: ‘Ignoring’ is negative. We want positivity in greetings/goodbyes!

activities.text: Hamesha yaad rakho: Last words leave strong impression. ‘Take care, bye!’ is always a safe close.

activities.sentence: Good ______ (morning/sadness)! Great to see you bright and early.
hints: One common greeting used early day

feedback.correctText: Yes, ‘Good morning’ is a cheerful start!
feedback.wrongText: ‘Good sadness’? That’s not a greeting at all!

scenes.text: Story: You see your boss: ‘Good morning, how are you?’ politely. Boss replies ‘Good morning, I'm fine. Thanks!’
You leave after short chat: ‘It was nice catching up. Goodbye for now!’

activities.question: While greeting boss or seniors, do you get nervous?

dynamicFeedback.0: Try short line + calm voice. Confidence aayegi slow-slow!
dynamicFeedback.1: Keep practicing polite lines from this lesson!
dynamicFeedback.3: Better to greet them politely than ignore!

activities.question: Best short greeting for your boss?

activities.title: Lesson 2 Recap
activities.body:
1) Greet with ‘Hello’/‘Hi’ + a warm tone
2) Use short positive lines to say goodbye
3) Hindi-English mix is ok—but polite vibe is #1
4) Smile & eye contact can amplify your greeting!

activities.description: How do you describe who you are, your hobbies, and more—without feeling shy? Let's tackle that next!

activities.title: Greetings & Goodbyes Champion!
activities.description: Congrats, Lesson 2 complete—ab aap confidently Hello/Bye bol sakte ho. Keep it up!
